titlestmt.titleproper:
Guide to the Troy E. Tull Photographic Slides of New York City and Elsewhere
(1970–1993)
PR 339
titlestmt.author: Finding aid prepared by Joseph Ditta, September 2017.

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using the Archivists' Toolkit 2017-09-01T13:40-0400

did.unittitle: Troy E. Tull photographic slides of New York City and elsewhere
did.abstract: 101 color photographic slides of New York City documenting the construction of the original World Trade Center, the Statue of Liberty, and Rockefeller Center at Christmas. Includes some views of Boston, San Francisco, and London.

accessrestrict.head: Access Restrictions
accessrestrict.p: Photocopying undertaken by staff only. Limited to twenty exposures of stable, unbound material per day. (Researchers may not accrue unused copy amounts from previous days.)

userestrict.head: Use Restrictions
userestrict.p: Permission to reproduce any Print Room holdings through publication must be obtained from: Rights and Reproductions, The New-York Historical Society, 170 Central Park West, New York, NY 10024. Phone: (212) 873-3400 ext. 270. Fax: (212) 579-8794.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The slides are grouped by topic and housed in a single box of six folders.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Tull’s photographs capture three of the main tourist sites in New York City: Rockefeller Center at Christmas, the Statue of Liberty, and the original World Trade Center. Tull photographed the latter in the early 1970s, when the WTC’s twin towers were still under construction. The collection includes general views of Manhattan (the skyline, prominent buildings, bridges, etc.), other locations in the United States (Boston, San Francisco, and Tull’s home in Teaneck, New Jersey), Europe (London), and a number of unidentified scenes.

bioghist.head: Biographical Note
bioghist.p: Troy Eugene Tull was born 1 April 1932 in Morrison, Oklahoma, and died 2 September 1995 in Edmond, Oklahoma. Tull was an IBM engineer whose career focused on the creation of UPC (Universal Product Code) technology and point of sale equipment. Between (roughly) 1960 and 1965 he lived and worked for IBM in Poughkeepsie, New York. The company next moved Tull to Boulder, Colorado, to manage the plant there. IBM then brought him back to New York in 1968–1971. During this period Tull lived with his family in Teaneck, New Jersey, and apparently also kept an apartment in Brooklyn. He later moved back to Boulder and then to his native Oklahoma, where he went into sales.

Tull was a camera enthusiast with his own darkroom who took thousands of rolls of film and photographic slides. He documented scenes that excited him, such as the construction of the original World Trade Center towers, which were rising during his second stint in New York (1968–1971). During a visit to Manhattan in the 1980s, to be close to the towers, he insisted on staying at the adjacent Vista International Hotel (later renamed Marriott World Trade Center).
[The preceding was adapted from notes supplied by the photographer’s son, Michael Tull.]

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: Processed by archivist Joseph Ditta, September 2017.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: This collection should be cited as the Troy E. Tull Photographic Slides of New York City and Elsewhere, PR 339, Department of Prints, Photographs, and Architectural Collections, The New-York Historical Society.
Credit line (for exhibition labels): Troy E. Tull.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Gift of Michael Tull (son of the photographer), April 2017.

did.unittitle: New York City: Manhattan (general views) [26 slides]
New York City: Rockefeller Center Christmas Tree, etc. [10 slides]
New York City: Statue of Liberty [13 slides]
New York City: World Trade Center construction [17 slides]
New Jersey: Teaneck house, etc. [20 slides]

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Tull lived with his family in Teaneck, New Jersey, 1968–1971.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Includes Boston [2 slides]; San Francisco [1 slide]; London [2 slides]; an unidentified European city [1 slide]; and unidentified locations [9 slides].
